newsitem.title: FRANCE: French car sales to drop 10-11 pct in 1997 - CCFA.
newsitem.headline: French car sales to drop 10-11 pct in 1997 - CCFA.

text.p: Sales of new cars in France will fall between 10 and 11 percent in 1997 to around 1.9 million, the French carmakers' association CCFA said on Tuesday.
Its forecast is in line with those of the two French carmakers, Renault SA and PSA Peugeot Citroen, which expect the market to shrink around 10 percent.

Car sales last year totalled 2.13 million units, bolstered by a rebate scheme that ran to the end of September 1996. For the first three months of 1997, sales are down 26.5 percent from year-earlier levels, but CCFA chairman Yves de Belabre said the market was expected to improve as the year wore on.
He told a news conference the distortionary effects of the rebates, which pulled sales forward as consumers rushed to take advantage of discounts, were starting to ease.

He also said the slow growth of the French car market, which has not recovered the 1989-1992 sales levels of more than two million units, suggests many old vehicles are due for replacement. "That's why we're reasonably optimistic," he said.
